Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the NSF Innovation Corps for Learning Program (I-Corps L), this project will develop ways to increase the scale and impact of a tutoring, mentoring, and advising program to help community college students to complete Associate's degrees and successfully transfer to four-year institutions. Increasing the number and diversity of students entering, persisting and graduating with STEM degrees; and significantly aiding them with STEM internships and job placements is imperative to solving the critical national and state workforce deficit that encompasses 63 STEM occupations categorized by the U. S. Department of Labor. Improving STEM education pathways to engage and retain students in STEM programs requires creative interdisciplinary real world experiential learning strategies that integrate technology in delivering and reiterating content to 21st century learners. Community colleges represent a special opportunity for increasing STEM majors. Two-year institutions are 'the entry point into higher education for most first-generation college students, particularly those from low-income, minority, and immigrant backgrounds'. Studies have shown that only 25 percent of these students complete a two-year degree and transfer to a four-year institution and only 17 percent complete a bachelor's degree. In 2000, the Baccalaureate and Beyond Community College Mentoring Program (BBCCMP) was founded to assist underrepresented minority, low income, and first generation community college students from six State University of New York (SUNY) community colleges with the transition from the two-year to four-year institutions and transitions either into the workforce or to graduate or professional school. The program involves tutoring, mentoring, and advising at the two and four-year institutions as well as a summer research program. In the almost fifteen years of the program, over 300 students have been involved. Over 80 percent of these students completed their Associate's degree and transferred to four-year institutions. Over 70 percent of these students are completing their bachelor's degree and 33 percent are going on for post-graduate work. This I-Corps for Learning project will develop ways to extend the impact of this program to other institutions throughout the country.

The BBCCMP Program at Purchase College provides an extensive array of student supports. These begin when the student is recruited from the community college. Faculty coordinators at the community college identify and advise students who wish to enter the program. In addition, the program provides peer tutors and mentors at the community college. Students participate in a summer research program that not only provides research opportunities, but also has workshops on skills building, transferring, and career and post-baccalaureate opportunities. Students also participate in cohort and career building. In 2010 the SUNY Replication Project created a New York-based ecosystem in STEM based on the success of the Baccalaureate and Beyond Program within SUNY. Subsequently, six regional hubs comprising a mixture of two-year and four-year institutions were formed, and representatives met again at a second conference in 2012, to scale-up working with community colleges on student transitions. Through the NSF I-Corps initiative, this project will investigate sustainable methods to expand the success of BBCCMP to a larger number of institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SUNY System Administration sought support and training through the I Corps L program to replicate a successful evidence-based and evidence-generating STEM education model, the Baccalaureate and Beyond Community College Mentoring Program for Community College Students (BBCCMP), developed at Purchase College. This program was founded to assist underrepresented minority, low income, and first generation community college students from six SUNY community colleges with the transition from the two-year to four-year institutions and transitions either into the workforce or to graduate or professional school. The Program involves tutoring, mentoring, and advising at the two and four-year institutions as well as a summer research program. The program was founded with an initial grant from the NIH Bridges to the Baccalaureate Program (NIH Grant # R25GM062012) that has been renewed and continues through 2024. The program was expanded with an NSF STEP grant (0524965) as well as other grants including an NSF CSEMS grant (0123208), an NSF CCLI grant (0941855) and an NSF S-STEM grant (1060417). In the almost sixteen years of the program, over 300 students have been involved. Over 80% of these students are completing their Associate’s degree and transferring to four-year institutions (40% to Purchase). Over 70% of these students are completing their bachelor’s degree and 33% are going on for post-graduate work. The program received the PAESMEM award in 2009.

The SUNY I Corps L Team sought to develop a less-expensive, replicable model for summer research that would preserve the important elements of the on-site model (research program, cohort building, mentoring, math preparation and E-portfolios). The Minimum Value Product (MVP) that arose after talking to over 100 individuals was a Blended (on-site and on-line) model described briefly below.

Online-learning Activities:

  • Pre-orientation Faculty Mentoring: Community College Faculty Coordinator will inform first-year students of the Blended Summer Program and will organize an early spring visit by the four-year faculty coordinator. Faculty mentoring will continue throughout the program.
  • Literature Review Presentation: Before the research residency, student lab groups will collaborate on developing a PowerPoint literature review presentation and present it on-line (via Zoom) to the cohort and faculty mentors.
  • Data Analysis / Progress Report Presentation: Student Lab groups will make PowerPoint progress reports prior to their on-site final presentations.
  • ·      Six-Week Course: The six-week online course will consist of three modules: 1) skills building (writing, math boot camp); 2) preparation for research (literature review, techniques, data analysis); and 3) presentation skills (writing, power point, poster preparation). This will be a mixture of real-time live online sessions and self-guided work.  

Face to Face On-Site Activities: 

  • Orientation: Students will participate in a half-day orientation at Purchase that includes an overview of the program, short presentations by the research faculty, and a meeting with their faculty mentor. This is a strong part of cohort building and has always been part of the summer residential program
  • Program Start: After orientation day, students will meet for a full day with their faculty mentor. Each lab group will have a teaching assistant who is a Purchase junior or senior. Lab group size is five students. Faculty mentors will outline the research projects, go over methodology, and introduce students to the literature in preparation for their literature review presentation
  • Residential Research Program: Students will engage in two weeks of original research as a group under the supervision of the faculty mentor and a teaching assistant. Students will spend approximately eight hours per day in the lab or in the field. Students will be introduced to data analysis in preparation for the on-line progress reports presentation. Possible projects that the students will be engaged in include:  
    • Testing the Antifungal Properties of Essential Oils and Synthesized Curcumin Derivatives, Sage Extracts and Tumeric Extracts
    • Aliens Among Us: Understanding the Dominance of an Invasive Species of Shore Crab, Hemigrapsus sanguineus
    • Assessing the Public Health Risk of Harmful Algal Bloom Occurrence in the Lower Hudson Valley
    • Using Biofilms to Detect Bacteria in Water from Fish Hatcheries
    • The Ups and Downs of Diversity: Interracial Interactions’ Effects on Physiological Responses, Executive Functioning and Behavioral Control

Intellectual Merit: The Blended Model developed under this I Corps L program is replicable and much les costly than the traditional on-site residential program.

Broader Impacts: This Blended model can be adapted to other liberal arts disciplines and to high school juniors and seniors and thus be a less costly model for a summer research experience.
